channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Voyagers explores complexities of coming of age in space
item.description: Director Neil Burger discusses how his film delves into the core of human nature

item.title: Lego has a new 2,354-piece NASA Space Shuttle set, and it’s awesome
item.description: The toymaker has had space shuttle sets in the past, but none as detailed as this.

item.title: Court rules grocery store’s inaccessible website isn’t an ADA violation
item.description: The Winn-Dixie website isn’t accessible for blind users with screen readers.

item.title: Diablo II Resurrected impressions: Unholy cow, man
item.description: Blizzard Classic follows WarCraft III’s utter failure with an udder success.

item.title: Variant hunters race to find new strains where variant testing lags
item.description: Scientists across Africa are collaborating to track them down.

item.title: Apple M1 hardware support merged into Linux 5.13
item.description: The merge is exciting, but don’t rush out to buy an Apple M1 for Linux just yet.

item.title: Russia cries “sabotage” after Slovakia questions quality of Sputnik vaccine
item.description: Russia now says it wants its vaccine back from Slovakia.

item.title: Google says the Pixel 5a will launch, but only in two countries
item.description: The Pixel 5a is getting Google’s smallest distribution ever, due to a lack of chips?

item.title: The big advance in Elon Musk’s Pong-playing monkey is what you can’t see
item.description: The company’s demo looks impressive, but most aspects have been done before.

item.title: Goldeneye successor unofficially unlocked as free bonus inside another game
item.description: Entirety of Goldeneye’s spiritual successor can be found inside of 2016’s Homefront.

item.title: No password required: Mobile carrier exposes data for millions of accounts
item.description: Q Link Wireless made data available to anyone who knows a customer’s phone number.

item.title: Report: Samsung may change course and begin selling OLED TVs
item.description: A deal with LG is close to being finalized, according to South Korean outlets.

item.title: 100,000 people ask Biden, will ya break that 2-2 FCC deadlock already?
item.description: Advocates urge Biden to quickly nominate someone who “will stand up to the ISPs.”

item.title: How a speedrunner broke Super Mario Bros.’ biggest barrier
item.description: Niftski’s sub-4:55 run required everything to come together perfectly.

item.title: Florida sues USA, CDC to get people back on cruise ships
item.description: Florida says vaccines make travel safe—but banned businesses from requiring them.

item.title: Our ancestors left Africa both with and without modern brains
item.description: The genus Homo originated with a brain that still had ape-like features.

item.title: The Nokia X20 brings 5G phones down to $415
item.description: The new Snapdragon 480 SoC brings 5G downmarket.

item.title: YouTube’s policies block ad targeting on Black Lives Matter videos
item.description: “Brand safety” partially dictates who can make money on YouTube.

item.title: There’s a lot to like about Honda’s efficient, affordable Accord Hybrid
item.description: Different trim levels show the effect of wheel size on fuel efficiency.

item.title: Amazon workers in Bessemer have voted not to form a union
item.description: The unionization vote had huge stakes for Amazon and the labor movement.

item.title: 2 recent studies sequence DNA from the earliest Homo sapiens in Eurasia
item.description: One study includes DNA from the son of Neanderthal and Homo sapiens parents.

item.title: US adds Chinese supercomputing companies to export blacklist
item.description: Biden administration tightens controls on tech that aids China’s military.

item.title: Comcast nightmare: Six months without Internet despite $5,000 payment
item.description: Comcast falsely said service was available, still hasn’t delivered six months later.

item.title: Windows and Linux devices are under attack by a new cryptomining worm
item.description: With new exploits and capabilities, the Sysrv botnet poses a growing threat.

item.title: Rocket Report: SpaceX abandons catching fairings, ULA bets on upper stages
item.description: “All of the resistance, that is going to be gradually disappearing.”

item.title: DNA analysis solves curious case of the stillborn fetus in the bishop’s coffin
item.description: The fetus was probably the grandson of 17th-century Swedish Bishop Peder Winstrup.

item.title: US COVID cases “disturbingly high” as Michigan sees dire spike
item.description: Michigan’s increases in cases, hospitalizations, deaths may be bellwether for country.

item.title: Apple, Epic Games lay out detailed arguments for upcoming legal battle
item.description: Is the App Store its own market or just one of many competing gaming markets?

item.title: The Apple Watch Series 6 is down to its lowest price yet today
item.description: But only the red model. Dealmaster also has Nest thermostats, monitors, � more.

item.title: FTC urges courts not to dismiss Facebook antitrust case
item.description: FTC blasts “anticompetitive actions to neutralize, hinder, or deter” competitors.

item.title: Lenovo’s gaming phone has an extreme dual-fan cooling system
item.description: Lenovo Legion Phone Duel 2 has 2 fans, 2 USB-C ports, and 6 shoulder buttons.

item.title: Amazon warns Texas: Don’t pass bill that would drive up wind power costs
item.description: Bill would “directly assign” grid stability costs to renewable power providers.

item.title: Why some investors are excited about Ryan Cohen as GameStop’s next chairman
item.description: Move comes as GameStop tries to cash in on its persistent stock surge.

item.title: T-Mobile 5G home Internet: $60 a month, 100Mbps speeds, and no data cap
item.description: 30 million households are eligible; signups available “until capacity runs out.”

item.title: Twitch takes additional steps to punish “off-Twitch” user harassment
item.description: New policy will focus on threats of violence, hate groups, and sexual offenses.

item.title: SpaceX landed a rocket on a boat five years ago—it changed everything
item.description: “We were like, well, we didn’t really account for that.”

item.title: Best Buy takes aim at Amazon Prime with its own membership program
item.description: The company’s new program should appeal to Geek Squad frequent fliers.

item.title: How a VPN vulnerability allowed ransomware to disrupt two manufacturing plants
item.description: Patching in industrial settings is hard. Ransomware shutting down production is harder.

item.title: How Apple’s new App Tracking Transparency policy works
item.description: Paper covers IDFA alternatives, rules for Apple’s own apps, and more.

item.title: Twitter won’t let federal archivists host Trump’s tweets on Twitter
item.description: Twitter is taking a hard-line stance on the banned @realDonaldTrump account.

item.title: When asked to fix something, we don’t even think of removing parts
item.description: Across many experiments, participants tried to fix problems by adding stuff.

item.title: Biden admin could set emissions limits so low gas cars can’t meet them
item.description: New rules will be written with climate mitigation in mind, new EPA chief said.

item.title: AstraZeneca vaccine linked to rare blood clots, EU regulators conclude
item.description: Link throws fate of AZ’s vaccine into question—and casts dark shadow over J�J’s vaccine.

item.title: Riders face long waits as Uber and Lyft struggle to recruit drivers
item.description: Riders are flooding back to ride-hailing apps. Drivers, not so much.

item.title: Dell Alienware launches its first AMD-powered gaming laptop since 2007
item.description: OEMs are finally starting to pair Ryzen Mobile with the most powerful GPUs.

item.title: SpaceX to keep Starlink pricing simple, exit beta when network is “reliable”
item.description: “We’re going to try to keep [pricing] as simple and transparent as possible.”

item.title: Watch us play Diablo II Resurrected before anyone else: Today at 1:30 pm ET
item.description: On 4/8, we’ll test (and livestream) D2:R’s technical alpha one day before its public launch.

item.title: Google is now writing low-level Android code in Rust
item.description: Google’s promotion of Rust over C and C++ should lead to fewer memory security bugs.

item.title: Fermilab’s latest muon measurements hint at cracks in the Standard Model
item.description: Only a 1-in-40,000 chance that combined results are due to a statistical fluctuation.

item.title: Microsoft Surface leak: Looks like the Surface Laptop 4 is coming soon
item.description: 2021 AMD-powered Microsoft Surface editions are one step closer to reality.

item.title: Honeywell releases details of its ion trap quantum computer
item.description: After its announcement roughly a year ago, we have a paper describing the details.

item.title: “Offsetting is a cop-out”: Polestar plans truly carbon-neutral car
item.description: The “Polestar 0” project will require new ways of building cars, says its CEO.

item.title: Nvidia now lets “RTX Voice” noise cancellation run on GTX-level cards
item.description: Lower-level requirement was quietly updated last September without much notice.

item.title: Google illegally tracking Android users, according to new complaint
item.description: Activist alleges use of tracking identifiers without user consent breaches EU law.

item.title: 99 Pac-Men enter, one Pac-Man leaves in new Switch freebie Pac-Man 99
item.description: Follows Tetris 99 as an included part of paid Nintendo Switch Online memberships.

item.title: Cruise industry salty over CDC plan to keep travelers safe from COVID at sea
item.description: CDC didn’t mandate vaccinations on board but added extra layers of protection.

item.title: Russia’s Twitter throttling may give censors never-before-seen capabilities
item.description: Censorship based on deep packet inspection may work against Tor and VPNs.

item.title: The best game deals we could find in the PlayStation and Xbox spring sales
item.description: Dealmaster also has plenty of deals on PC games across various sales.

item.title: Intel’s Ice Lake Xeon comes out swinging at AMD’s Epyc Milan
item.description: Chipzilla’s new server processors bring more cores, more RAM, more features.

item.title: Chip shortage shows no signs of abating, may drag into 2022
item.description: It’s not just manufacturing capacity—wafer and packaging remain constrained.

item.title: Yahoo Answers to end as Trump fans see plot to “silence conservatives”
item.description: “Should Trump buy Yahoo to prevent Answers from being shut down?” user asks.

item.title: tvOS code hints at a new Apple TV 4K with 120 Hz playback
item.description: Higher frame rates mean smoother interfaces and better gameplay experiences.

item.title: Sand, sun, and electric off-road SUVs: Extreme E holds its first race
item.description: There’s a lot to like about this new environmentally conscious race series.

item.title: How the Supreme Court saved the software industry from API copyrights
item.description: The Supreme Court surprised everyone with its API copyright ruling.

item.title: Pixel 5 sees dramatically improved GPU performance after April patch
item.description: It’s not an amazing improvement; the Pixel 5 GPU was just really bad to begin with.

item.title: NASA’s most metal mission will test new, higher-power electric thrusters
item.description: This is the first time a spacecraft has gone into deep space using Hall thrusters.

item.title: Want to worry about the next pandemic? Spillover.global has you covered
item.description: A research collaboration has evaluated hundreds of viruses based on human risk.

item.title: Celebrate First Contact Day with this Star Trek: Discovery S4 trailer
item.description: “Federation or non-Federation, this anomaly threatens us equally.”
